name: Gridworld
description: Gridworld is an artificial life / evolution simulator in which abstract virtual creatures compete for food and struggle for survival. Conditions in this two-dimensional ecosystem are right for evolution to occur through natural selection.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 64-bit or higher Processor: 2.0 Ghz Quad Core CPU Memory: 8 GB RAM Storage: 200 MB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 64-bit or higher Processor: 2.4 Ghz Quad Core CPU or faster Memory: 8 GB RAM Storage: 500 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Absolutely the best idle game out there:
for one buck this game will destroy your life.

A relaxing and fun to watch evolution simulator, i often run it in the background while playing other games or doing work on my computer, it is fun to play with the different simulation settings and seeing what mutations become prominent because of the settings.
I literally have no ♥♥♥♥ing idea whats going on.   The colors are pretty though.

-Created a world -Got bored with it -Inported an evolved creature -The species killed everything including itself (it ate all the food) -Tried again -Cool creature evolved naturally -Began to expand across the world eating everything -Placed the evolved creature in to compete -Everything starved  Edit: -Created a creature that moves around and creates food -Saved the world from starvation  Edit: -Turns out that what I thought was food was actually poison -Didn't matter- the creature kept dying out because it couldn't eat  10/10 would cause (and then try to fix but fail epically) a mass extinction event again
Dubbed a species that had an oddly symmetrical brown pattern on their backs Brownbacks (and also a purple variant) after about 3-4 hours of waiting.  10/10 would Brownback again

-Started New World  -Jolly 'ole pixels eating away a green sea of yummy paradise  -One of them isn't moving  -First one dies 10 seconds in  -Sees organism with potential to reproduce  -Organism dies within 5 seconds of me seeing it  -One minute in everything has died out  -Waits 15 more minutes for something to happen  -Nothing happens  TheDeadDoNotRise/10
Be aware that this is not a game, it is a Petri Vase simulation.  Still, it is the best Sea Monkey simulation I've ever seen
Game is extremely slow once any sizeable creature count/complexity is reached. Crashes are common. Great idea, but clunky UI and slow/unreliable gameplay make this sim unplayable.
Unless you want to wait 10 hours, no, it is not fun, at all It's more 'pretty' than anything else.
Quite simply, it is not a thing I enjoyed in any way. Even collecting the trading cards was a pain. Would you enjoy it? Yes, if you're not a gamer.
I love it :D Cheap and nice. It's not a game but it is really nice to watch how all live is creating. Worth 0.99 :D

Pretty nice concept. UI needs to be a bit more user - friendly but you will find your way after a while. Nice one! Price tag is acceptable so don't overthink. Just buy it and I will buy you a coffee tomorrow.

I found this game over the steam winter sales and thought, oh another simulation game that made you feel like a genius for observing fake organisms, and then after seeing that it was only 99 cents decided what the hell. I bought the game and started playing, trying to figure out how to make something that was self-sufficient whenI realized how much time I was spending. This game is bound to keep you entertained for a few hours, it did for me, and more often than not the random creatures spawned will beat what you're trying to make, but will completely fail for a while, so have fun with it.
It may be confusing for the first few moments. But waiting and looking up videos of it makes playing a whole lot better.
